citations.narrative:
There were 4 enclosures that had inadequate shelters for the wolf-dog hybrids contained in the enclosure. In 2 outdoor
enclosures the shelters had no wind break or rain break at the entrance. In 2 other outdoor enclosures, 3 transport crates
were provided for shelter and these did not have a wind break or rain break at the entrance. The use of transport crates is
considered inadequate for a shelter as there are large openings on 3 sides that expose the dogs to wind and rain while in
the shelter. Wind breaks and rain breaks are important to protect the dogs from the weather elements and must be
provided at all times.
b) Shelter from the elements. Outdoor facilities for dogs must include one or more shelter structures that are accessible to
each animal in each outdoor facility, and that are large enough to allow each animal in the shelter structure to sit, stand,
and lie in a normal manner, and to turn about freely. In addition to the shelter structures, one or more separate outside
areas of shade must be provided, large enough to contain all the animals at one time and protect them from the direct
rays of the sun. Shelters in outdoor facilities for dogs or cats must contain a roof, four sides, and a floor, and must:
(b)(1) Provide the dogs with adequate protection and shelter from the cold and heat;
(b)(2) Provide the dogs with protection from the direct rays of the sun and the direct effect of wind, rain, or snow;
(b)(3) Be provided with a wind break and rain break at the entrance; and
(b)(4) Contain clean, dry, bedding material if the ambient temperature is below 50 °F (10 °C). Additional clean, dry
bedding is required when the temperature is 35 °F (1.7 °C) or lower.
Correction date: 19 February 2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
